title: Bharatanatyam
short_description: One of the oldest classical dance forms, known for its fixed upper torso, bent legs, and spectacular footwork.
long_description:
Bharatanatyam is widely regarded as the oldest surviving classical dance tradition in India. Originating in the temples of Tamil Nadu, it was originally performed by female temple dancers called Devadasis and was known as Dasi Attam. The name Bharatanatyam is often interpreted as a combination of three concepts: Bha-va (Expression), Ra-ga (Main Melody), and Ta-la (Rhythm), with Natyam meaning dance.

This art form is renowned for its sculptural poses, the grounded stance known as 'Aramandi' (half-sit), and intricate footwork that creates a complex rhythmic interplay with the accompanying music. The dance is traditionally a solo performance that narrates stories from Hindu mythology, particularly those of Lord Shiva, Krishna, and the Goddess. 

The repertoire is divided into Nritta (pure dance with rhythm and movement), Nritya (combination of rhythm and expression), and Natya (dramatic element). A traditional recital, or Margam, follows a specific order starting with Alarippu (an offering of flowers) and concluding with Tillana (a fast-paced rhythmic piece).

Over the centuries, Bharatanatyam has evolved from temple precincts to royal courts and finally to public stages, becoming a symbol of India's cultural identity globally.
costume_and_makeup: Dancers wear a specially stitched Kanchipuram silk saree that fans out during movements. Jewelry includes the 'talai-saman' (headset representing sun and moon), temple jewelry necklaces, grand bangles, and ghungroos (bells) on the ankles. Makeup highlights the eyes to enhance expression, and fingertips are painted red to draw attention to mudras.
key_traditions: Prayer to Lord Nataraja before starting

top_places.title: The Music Academy, Chennai
top_places.summary: The premier institution for Carnatic music and Bharatanatyam performs.
top_places.how_to_reach: Located in Mylapore, Chennai; accessible by taxi or bus.

top_places.title: Thillai Nataraja Temple, Chidambaram
top_places.summary: The spiritual home of the Lord of Dance, Nataraja. The Natyanjali festival is held in the temple precincts.

top_places.title: Kalakshetra Foundation
top_places.summary: A center for artistic endeavor founded by Rukmini Devi Arundale. Offers beautiful morning assemblies and performances.

top_places.title: Thanjavur Royal Palace
top_places.summary: Visit the Brihadeeswarar Temple nearby, which has 108 karanas (dance poses) carved in stone.
top_places.how_to_reach: Thanjavur is well-connected by rail from Chennai and Trichy.

top_places.title: Mamallapuram Dance Festival
top_places.summary: Open-air festival held against the backdrop of ancient rock sculptures.
top_places.how_to_reach: 60km south of Chennai along the ECR.

practical_info.audience_tips: Applause is reserved for the end of a piece (varnam, tillana). Do not take flash photography during performances as it distracts dancers.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Major auditoriums in Chennai are wheelchair accessible, but temple venues may have steps.
practical_info.suggested_attire_for_viewers: Smart casual or traditional Indian wear is appreciated at sabhas (cultural organizations).

teaching_workshop_details.booking_info: Contact Kalakshetra or private gurus in Mylapore for short-term workshops.
